Award.AwardTitle: BiSn/CNT Nanocomposite as Novel Thermal Interface Material

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
0966908

Chen

Thermal interface material (TIM) is used to bond electronic devices to heat spreaders for thermal management purposes. Desirable attributes of TIM include a low melting temperature, necessary for device protection during bonding, good bonding strength, and low thermal resistance. This research will develop a BiSn/carbon nanotube composite material to meet these design requirements.

Intellectual Merit: An electrochemical deposition process will be developed for which uniformly-distributed carbon nanotubes and good interfacial bonding can be achieved. The BiSn/carbon nanotube material will be blended to meet the design requirements and to tailor the coefficient of thermal expansion so as to promote durability of the bond. Experimental approaches will be taken to measure the resultant properties of BiSn/carbon nanotube composite material. Both microscopic observations and quantum calculations will be carried out to understand the pertinent thermal conduction mechanisms.

Broader Impacts: The proposed bonding material and method can improve the thermal management of advanced electronics including but not limited to integrated circuitry, power electronics, and various laser systems. The research will be integrated into both undergraduate and graduate courses. Graduate and undergraduate students will be involved in the research. Existing K-12 outreach programs will be leveraged while a new summer camp for high school teachers will be developed.

Institution.Name: The University of Central Florida Board of Trustees
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF CENTRAL FLORIDA BOARD OF TRUSTEES, THE

Performance_Institution.Name: The University of Central Florida Board of Trustees

POR.DRECONTENT:
The award aimed to integrate carbon nanotubes with thermal interface materials including SnBi alloy to significantly increase the thermal and mechanical properties. Several material processing methods have been used to add carbon nanotubes into metals, such as electrochemical co-deposition, powder metallurgy and casting. The combination of electrochemical deposition with both powder metallurgy and casting have proven successful in obtaining uniformly dispersed carbon nanotubes in metal together with a good interfacial bonding.  The resultant mechanical strength of Sn and BiSn alloy has been increased by about 100%, and the thermal conductivity has been increased by 170% when compared to pure metals.       

Two Ph.D. students have been supported towards their complete. Three journal papers have been published plus two more journal papers to be published. In addition to graduate students, undergraduate students and high school students were also involved in the project and were trained to conduct the related research. 

The success of this award will provide foundation for developing many different type of composites, including but not limited to, other metallic composites, polymer based composites, as well as ceramic based composites. The success of BiSn/CNT composite will be very important for IC industry since the significantly increased thermal and mechanical properties are critical for solders/thermal interfacial materials in powder electronics including packaging.   

  

 

 


Last Modified: 01/29/2017
Modified by: Quanfang Chen
